exercises.name: Hanging Leg Raise
exercises.description: The hanging leg raise is a high‑tension abdominal exercise that targets the lower rectus abdominis while demanding serious grip and shoulder stability. Each strict leg lift forces the hip flexors and deep core to keep the torso motionless, teaching full‑body control and improving posture. Because it requires only a sturdy bar, it is a staple for calisthenics athletes, gymnasts, and lifters seeking sharper mid‑section definition. Progressively adding ankle weights or a dumbbell between the feet keeps the movement challenging even for advanced trainees.
steps: The hanging leg raise is an awesome exercise for building the lower abs. All you need for this exercise is somewhere to hang from. It could be a chinup bar or it could be a tree.
Once you"re hanging, tense up the mid section. While keeping your legs straight, raise your them up slowly. You should raise your legs are high as possible.
Pause for a second, and slowly lower your legs back to the starting position.
Repeat for desired reps.
Speed is so important with the hanging leg raise. If you swing your legs, you"re using momentum and your abs will not benefit much from the exercise.
Do not allow your body to swing. Keep your torso as still and controlled as possible.
Advanced lifters can add weight by holding a dumbbell between the feet.
tips: Speed is so important with the hanging leg raise. If you swing your legs, you"re using momentum and your abs will not benefit much from the exercise.
Do not allow your body to swing. Keep your torso as still and controlled as possible.
Advanced lifters can add weight by holding a dumbbell between the feet.

exercises.name: Plank
exercises.description: The plank is a core-strengthening exercise that targets the abdominals, lower back, shoulders, and glutes. Planks help build endurance, enhance balance, and prevent injuries by strengthening the muscles that support the spine. They also promote better posture and can improve athletic performance. With no equipment needed, planks are a versatile and efficient exercise for developing core strength and stability, making them a must-have in any fitness routine.
steps: Start by lying face down on the floor. Place your forearms on the ground, elbows directly below your shoulders.
Position your feet hip-width apart with your toes tucked under.
Push through your forearms and toes to lift your body off the floor.
Your body should form a straight line from your head to your heels. Keep your neck neutral by looking straight down, not forward.
Tighten your core (imagine pulling your belly button toward your spine) and squeeze your glutes to prevent your hips from sagging or rising.
Hold the position for as long as you can while maintaining good form.
tips: If you're new to planks, it's important to build strength and endurance gradually. Here's a beginner progression to help you work up to a full plank:

Wall Plank: Stand facing a wall and place your hands on it at shoulder height. Step your feet back slightly and bend your elbows to create a straight line from your head to your heels. Hold for 30 seconds, focusing on keeping your core tight.
Incline Plank: Use a bench or sturdy surface. Place your forearms on the bench and your feet on the floor, forming a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core and hold for 30 seconds.
Knee Plank: Start in a standard plank position but with your knees on the ground instead of your toes. Keep your body in a straight line from head to knees, engaging your core. Hold for 30 seconds.

Wall Plank: Stand facing a wall and place your hands on it at shoulder height. Step your feet back slightly and bend your elbows to create a straight line from your head to your heels. Hold for 30 seconds, focusing on keeping your core tight.
Incline Plank: Use a bench or sturdy surface. Place your forearms on the bench and your feet on the floor, forming a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core and hold for 30 seconds.
Knee Plank: Start in a standard plank position but with your knees on the ground instead of your toes. Keep your body in a straight line from head to knees, engaging your core. Hold for 30 seconds.
Keep breathing steadily through the nose and mouth.
Keep your body in a straight line, and avoid letting your hips sag or rise.
Gradually increase your hold time by 5-10 seconds as you build strength.
If holding for longer is too difficult, try breaking it into shorter sets (e.g., 2 sets of 20 seconds).

exercises.name: Sit Up
exercises.description: The sit up is a classic abdominal exercise. It's rarely performed anymore, however, it's still a very effective flexion based exercise for those looking to utilize it to target their core. There are some risks involved in performing the sit up as opposed to crunches (or stability ball crunches). The primary one being the common complaint of lower back pain. One can perform sit ups as part of their ab workout or full body workout.
steps: Lay supine in a relaxed position with your knees up and hands across your chest.
Exhale and squeeze your abs as you curl your upper body off the floor.
Once your torso is perpendicular to the floor, slowly lower yourself back to the starting position.
Complete for the assigned number of repetitions.
tips: Exhale hard like you're blowing out candles on a cake and hold the contraction for a second in order to improve mind muscle connection.
If your lower back bothers you during this exercise, choose more anti extension and anti rotation based movements.
Avoid putting the hands behind the head as this can lead to excess strain upon the neck.

exercises.name: Abdominal Air Bike (AKA Bicycle)
exercises.description: The abdominal air bike is probably the most feared abdominal movement from anyone who's performed an at-home ab workout video. The bicycle exercise targets the whole abdomen and places constant tension on the mid-section as you go through the motions on both sides. This exercise is an advanced variation of a crunch. It can be performed for timed sets or as a set with a fixed rep range.
steps: Lay supine in a relaxed position with your arms behind your head and legs straight.
Exhale as you raise one knee towards your face while driving the opposite elbow to the knee.
Once your abs are fully contracted, slowly lower yourself back to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.
Complete for the assigned number of repetitions.
tips: Exhale hard like you're blowing out candles on a cake and hold the contraction for a second in order to improve mind muscle connection.
If your lower back bothers you during this exercise, choose more anti extension and anti rotation based movements.
Avoid putting the hands behind the head as this can lead to excess strain upon the neck.
contraindications: Severe cardiovascular issues (for heavy compound movements)

exercises.name: Dead Bug
exercises.description: The deadbug is an exercise used to strengthen the muscles of the abs. The exercise stems from the plank exercise family tree. The deadbug works as an anti-extension abdominal exercise in which you must keep the spine stable as you slowly raise your arm overhead. The deadbug gets its name because you look like a dead bug on its back with its legs in the air when you are performing the exercise.
steps: Setup in a supine position with your legs in a 90/90 position (90 degree bend at the hips and knees) and your arms reaching towards the ceiling.
Extend the opposite arm and leg simultaneously as you exhale.
Return back to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.
Repeat for the desired number of total repetitions.
tips: Do not hold your breath, you shouldn't be using respiration to compensate for a lack of stability. Learn how to move while maintaining position without having to rely upon your breath.
Move slowly but methodically. The goal is control within space, not simply completion of repetitions.
Ensure that you exhale as the arm moves overhead and the leg extends. The goal is to keep the ribs down and prevent the lower back from hyperextending.

If you can't maintain a neutral spine while moving the arm and leg simultaneously, then begin with just the arms or legs by themselves. Only incorporate more elements when you've mastered control of the individual components.
contraindications: Severe cardiovascular issues (for heavy compound movements)

exercises.name: Lying Leg Raise With Hip Thrust
exercises.description: The lying leg raise with hip thrust marries a controlled leg lift with a pelvic curl to super‑charge lower‑abdominal activation. After raising the legs to vertical, the deliberate hip thrust rolls the tailbone off the bench, eliminating momentum and forcing the entire abdominal wall to contract. This sequence trains anti‑extension strength, enhances lumbo‑pelvic stability, and delivers a deep burn that standard leg raises often miss. Performed with body‑weight or a light dumbbell held between the feet, it offers a scalable, joint‑friendly path to stronger, better‑defined lower abs.
steps: The lying bench leg raise with hip thrust is a great exercise for hitting your abdominal muscles. Set up for the exercise by getting a flat bench and positioning it to give enough room for your legs to extend out one end.
Sit on the bench with your buttocks close to one end, then lay back.
Grasp the bench at head height for stability.
Extend your legs straight out level with your body, keeping your knees and feet together. This is the starting position for the movement.
Bending at the hips only, slowly raise your legs up until they are pointing straight up.
At this point lift your pelvis off the bench as high as possible.
Lower your pelvis back down, and slowly lower your feet back to the starting position.
Complete the entire exercise slowly.
Add intensity by pausing at the top of the hip thrust, or hold a dumbbell with your feet.
tips: Complete the entire exercise slowly.
Add intensity by pausing at the top of the hip thrust, or hold a dumbbell with your feet.
contraindications: Severe cardiovascular issues (for heavy compound movements)

exercises.name: Hollow Body Crunch with Arm Sweep
exercises.description: A comprehensive core exercise that combines a crunch movement with an overhead arm sweep, targeting multiple areas of the abdominal wall while maintaining proper spinal positioning. This exercise emphasizes core control and teaches proper hollow body position, making it excellent for both strength and stability.
steps: Lie flat on your back with arms extended overhead and knees bent, feet flat on the floor.
Press your lower back firmly into the ground by engaging your core.
Begin by sweeping your arms forward while curling your upper back off the ground.
Reach forward with your arms as you crunch up, keeping your neck neutral.
Pause briefly at the top of the movement.
Lower back down with control, returning arms overhead.
Maintain constant pressure between your lower back and the floor throughout.
tips: Keep your lower back pressed into the floor throughout the entire movement.
Move slowly and controlled, focusing on the core contraction.
Avoid pulling with your neck - keep your gaze toward the ceiling.
Think about curling up one vertebra at a time.
Breathe out as you crunch up, in as you lower.

exercises.name: Plank to Push-Up
exercises.description: A dynamic plank variation that combines core stability with upper body strength. Starting from a forearm plank, you transition to a high plank position and back, challenging core anti-rotation while engaging shoulders and arms. Also known as Plank Up-Downs, this exercise builds functional strength and coordination.
steps: Start in a forearm plank with elbows directly under shoulders and body forming a straight line.
Engage your core and glutes to maintain a rigid plank position.
Press up onto your right hand, then left hand, arriving in a high plank position.
Lower back down one arm at a time, starting with right forearm, then left.
Return to the starting forearm plank position.
Alternate your leading arm with each repetition.
Maintain a stable core throughout the movement.
tips: Keep your hips as steady as possible, avoiding rotation or swaying.
Maintain a strong core brace throughout the entire movement.
Move at a controlled pace focusing on stability rather than speed.
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
If struggling, perform from knees until core strength improves.

exercises.name: Spiderman Plank
exercises.description: A dynamic plank variation where you bring each knee to its same-side elbow, combining core stability with hip mobility. Also known as Same-Side Knee-to-Elbow Mountain Climber, this exercise particularly targets the obliques while maintaining full-body tension through the plank position.
steps: Start in a high plank position with hands directly under shoulders and body forming a straight line.
Engage your core and maintain a strong plank position.
Bring your right knee toward your right elbow in a controlled motion.
Return the right leg to the starting position.
Repeat the movement with your left knee to left elbow.
Continue alternating sides while maintaining a stable core.
Keep your movements controlled and deliberate.
tips: Keep your core engaged throughout the entire movement.
Avoid letting your hips sag or pike up during the knee drives.
Move slowly and controlled rather than rushing through repetitions.
Breathe steadily throughout the exercise.
Focus on maintaining shoulder stability as you move.

exercises.name: Mountain Climbers
exercises.description: This is a high-intensity cardio and core drill where you rapidly alternate driving your knees toward your chest from a plank position. The version in your image involves a more explosive, jumping-style movement—less like "climbing" and more like switch jumps in plank form. It lights up the hip flexors, shoulders, and abs while spiking heart rate.
steps: Start in a high plank position with hands directly under shoulders and body forming a straight line.
Engage your core and ensure your shoulders are stacked over your wrists.
Explosively drive your right knee toward your chest, then quickly switch legs in a jumping motion.
Continue alternating legs at a rapid pace, keeping your core tight and body stable.
Focus on maintaining a strong plank position while driving the knees forward.
Continue for the desired duration or repetition count.
Keep the pace fast but controlled throughout the movement.
tips: Keep hands stacked under shoulders throughout the exercise.
Drive knees explosively without bouncing hips too high.
Brace your core to avoid sagging or arching the lower back.
Go fast, but stay clean—tempo > flailing.
Breathe rhythmically with the movement to maintain energy.
Start with shorter intervals (20-30 seconds) and build endurance over time.
For greater challenge, increase speed or add ankle weights.
To modify, slow the pace or perform from an elevated surface.
